III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• It was recommended to the facility that they develop a more detailed
documentation of overnight room check logs. They agreed to make the
recommended changes to the logs.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• The facility did not request consultation at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
2

Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
A review of the progress of the CAP was completed on 9/12/23 and it was
discovered the facilty has begun to follow through with the action steps of the CAP.
Training for mandated reporting has been completed and is scheduled twice a year.
Training on incident reporting has occurred and is scheduled for future dates.
During staff meeting both of these issues are discussed and the facilty provided a
copy of the agenda and the staff sign in sheet. A review of the training records has
been completed and the facilty provided a copy of this check sheet. Unannounced
performance checks have been completed twice a week and on each shift as
documented by the facility. Weekly round up meeting are documented as occuring
and weekly meeting with the Chief Operation Officer and Chief Adminstrator(CA)
are documented as occurring. Finally, the CA has documentation of meeting with
Dr. Thorpe monthly.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility's
budget and the agency's financial audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
N/A
Chief Administrator Assessment
The CA identified the special investigation 2023C0000328 as occurring because of
barriers that caused the rule violations. These barriers are identified as staff not
knowing their responsibilities involving incident reporting and mandated reporting
requirements. The CA also identified her responsible of causing a problem between
two youth when she took an item from one of the youth. Two other barriers were
identified as employing appropriate staff and the admission criteria for placements.
The CAP identified for this special investigation is identified as having a positive
impact on the facility and providing a direction for growth in the area of compliance.
Although they are struggling to hire enough staff, the process of this hiring has
increased the standards of the employees. Training has taken place and increased
the staff’s awareness of issues and their ability to provide appropriate services to
the youth. Staff are presenting better outcomes and decision making when
observed by administration during unannounced supervision checks. The changes
in the admission process have increased the ability for placement of appropriate
youth who have a chance of success in the program. The development of oversight
has led to positive outcomes and improved the services being provided. The CA
reported there have been no unplanned discharges during this reporting period.
The CA identified the need to improve the program statement in regard to
3

admission criteria. These changes are described as helping reach a standard of a
good fit which increases success for youth.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Interviews with staff were conducted and all staff interviewed reported being
supported by administration. They also reported the facility is providing training to
help staff provide the care the youth require.
Interviews with the youth were conducted and all youth reported feeling safe and
cared for by the staff at the facility. They reported being provided appropriate food
and personal items for their care.
Description of Agency Walk Through
This is a three-story older structure close to downtown Kalamazoo, Mi. The
structure is in fair condition and documentation indicates regular maintenance
occurs. The facility is furnished appropriately, and each bedroom has the required
items present. All plumbing is working appropriately, and the facility had an ample
amount of food which included fresh vegetables and fruit and the menu was
posted. Medication and cleaning supplies were locked appropriately, and
emergency number were posted. Overnight room check logs and emergency drill
logs were reviewed and all met the requirements.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. It is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
